home.title: Welcome to Dr. Qian Yuan's Research
home.content: Dr. Qian Yuan is a leading researcher in geophysics, geochemistry, igneous petrology, and geochronology. Our research focuses on understanding Earth's deep processes, planetary formation, and the evolution of our planet through time.

sections.title: Research Focus
sections.content: Our interdisciplinary approach combines geophysical modeling, geochemical analysis, and petrological studies to investigate fundamental questions about Earth's structure and evolution.

sections.title: Current Projects
sections.content: We are currently investigating the giant impact origin of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs), subduction initiation processes, and the geochemical signatures preserved in various mineral systems.

research.title: Research Overview
research.content: Our research spans multiple disciplines within Earth sciences, focusing on understanding the fundamental processes that shape our planet. We employ cutting-edge analytical techniques and computational modeling to investigate Earth's deep structure and evolution.

sections.title: Geophysics
sections.content: We study Earth's deep structure using seismic data and numerical modeling to understand mantle dynamics and the origin of large-scale heterogeneities.

sections.title: Geochemistry
sections.content: Our geochemical research focuses on isotopic systems that preserve information about Earth's early history and ongoing processes.

sections.title: Igneous Petrology
sections.content: We investigate magmatic processes and the formation of igneous rocks to understand crustal evolution and mantle-crust interactions.

sections.title: Geochronology
sections.content: Using advanced dating techniques, we determine the timing of geological processes and construct temporal frameworks for Earth's evolution.

research.researchAreasSubtitle: Explore our cutting-edge research across multiple disciplines in Earth sciences
research.methodologyContent: We employ cutting-edge analytical techniques and computational methods to understand Earth's complex processes across multiple scales and time periods.

news.title: Latest News & Updates
news.content: Stay updated with our latest research findings, publications, and team achievements.

newsItems.title: New Research Published in Nature Geoscience
newsItems.excerpt: Our latest study on the giant impact origin of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces has been published in Nature Geoscience, providing new insights into Earth's early bombardment history.
newsItems.content: This groundbreaking research presents compelling evidence that the mysterious Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs) in Earth's lower mantle may be remnants of ancient giant impact events. Using advanced numerical modeling and seismic analysis, our team has demonstrated how impact-generated material could have settled in the lower mantle and persisted for billions of years.

newsItems.title: Dr. Yuan Receives NSF CAREER Award
newsItems.excerpt: Principal Investigator Dr. Qian Yuan has been awarded the prestigious NSF CAREER Award for research on early Earth evolution and mantle dynamics.
newsItems.content: The National Science Foundation CAREER Award recognizes early-career faculty who have the potential to serve as academic role models in research and education. This five-year, $500,000 award will support Dr. Yuan's research on understanding the formation and evolution of Earth's deep structure through the integration of geophysical modeling and geochemical analysis.

newsItems.title: New Collaboration with Stanford University
newsItems.excerpt: We are excited to announce a new research collaboration with Stanford University's Department of Geophysics to study subduction initiation processes.
newsItems.content: This collaboration brings together expertise in computational geodynamics and seismic tomography to investigate the mechanisms that trigger the onset of subduction. The partnership will involve joint field work, shared computational resources, and student exchange programs.

newsItems.title: Graduate Student Wins Best Poster Award
newsItems.excerpt: PhD student Michael Chen received the Best Poster Award at the American Geophysical Union Fall Meeting for his work on mantle convection modeling.
newsItems.content: Michael's poster presentation on 'High-Resolution Modeling of Mantle Convection with Compositional Heterogeneities' impressed judges with its innovative approach to understanding how chemical variations in the mantle affect convection patterns. This research has important implications for understanding the long-term evolution of Earth's interior.

newsItems.title: Featured in National Geographic Documentary
newsItems.excerpt: Our research on Earth's early evolution will be featured in an upcoming National Geographic documentary about the formation of our planet.
newsItems.content: The documentary, titled 'Birth of a Planet,' will showcase our work on giant impacts and their role in shaping Earth's structure. Filming included interviews with team members and visualization of our computational models. The documentary is scheduled to air in spring 2024.

newsItems.title: New Equipment Enhances Laboratory Capabilities
newsItems.excerpt: Installation of a new high-precision mass spectrometer significantly expands our analytical capabilities for isotopic studies.
newsItems.content: The new Thermo Fisher Scientific Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS enables us to perform ultra-high precision isotopic measurements on small sample sizes. This capability is crucial for our research on early Earth materials and will support multiple ongoing projects in geochemistry and geochronology.

join.positionsSubtitle: Current opportunities to join our research team

positions.title: PhD Student in Geophysics
positions.description: We are seeking a motivated PhD student to work on computational modeling of mantle convection and early Earth evolution. The successful candidate will develop numerical models to understand the formation and evolution of Large Low Shear Velocity Provinces (LLSVPs).
requirements: Bachelor's degree in Geophysics, Physics, Mathematics, or related field
Strong background in mathematics and physics
Excellent written and verbal communication skills
benefits: Full funding including tuition and stipend

positions.title: Postdoctoral Researcher in Geochemistry
positions.description: We invite applications for a postdoctoral position focused on isotope geochemistry and early Earth processes. The researcher will work on understanding the chemical evolution of Earth's mantle through isotopic analysis of ancient rocks and minerals.
requirements: PhD in Geochemistry, Earth Sciences, or related field
Experience with mass spectrometry and isotope analysis
Ability to work independently and collaboratively
benefits: Research funds for travel and equipment

positions.title: Undergraduate Research Assistant
positions.description: Undergraduate students interested in Earth sciences research are encouraged to apply for research assistant positions. Students will gain hands-on experience in laboratory techniques, data analysis, and scientific research.
requirements: Major in Earth Sciences, Physics, Chemistry, or related field
Commitment of at least one semester
benefits: Potential for course credit or paid position
Mentorship from graduate students and faculty

applicationProcess.title: Decision

join.contactSubtitle: We're always interested in hearing from motivated individuals who share our passion for understanding Earth's evolution.

opportunities.description: We are seeking PhD students with strong backgrounds in geophysics, geochemistry, or related fields.
Postdoc positions are available for researchers with expertise in numerical modeling or analytical geochemistry.
